      a net increase of $88 million from higher prices on a higher volume of BGS contracts modestly offset by the expiration of several contracts in May 2008, and</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

      a net decrease of $68 million due to lower prices on a reduced sales volume to third party customers.</FONT>
    <P style="text-indent:12.7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>

    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>
      Trading </I></B>revenues increased $16 million principally due to premiums received on the termination of certain trades and gains on electric-related contracts.</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Operating Expenses</B></FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><FONT style="font-size:4.2mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>
      Energy Costs </I></B>represent the cost of generation, which includes fuel purchases for generation as well as purchased energy in the market, and gas purchases to meet Power&#146;s obligation under its BGSS contract with PSE&amp;G. Energy Costs decreased by $127 million due to:</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>



<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:3.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:5.6mm; ">
      <font face="Wingdings 2">&#161;</font></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>
      Generation costs </B>decreased by $39 million due to $98 million of lower fuel costs, primarily reflecting lower volumes of natural gas and coal purchases and lower average natural gas prices, partly offset by net losses of $51 million from financial hedging transactions.</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:5.6mm; "><font face="Wingdings 2">&#161;</font></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Gas costs </B>decreased $88 million, reflecting net decreases of $9 million and $75 million related to Power&#146;s obligations under the BGSS contract and sales to third party customers, respectively, reflecting lower inventory costs partially offset by higher volumes.</FONT></P>
    <P style="text-indent:12.7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">For the quarter ended March 31, 2009, the primary reasons for the $13 million decrease in Income from Continuing Operations were:</FONT></P>

      higher taxes as a result of tax benefits recorded in 2008 related to an IRS refund claim and other tax items, and</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>

    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">increased Operation and Maintenance expense and depreciation, offset by</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>

    <TD align="right">

    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">higher margin revenues due to favorable weather and a Transmission formula rate increase.</FONT></P>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="13" align="center"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>
      Increase/
      (Decrease)</B></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>For the quarter ended March 31, 2009 as compared to 2008</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Operating Revenues </B>increased $117 million primarily due to</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-size:4.2mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>
      Commodity </I></B>related revenues increased $65 million due to</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>



<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:3.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:5.6mm; ">
      <font face="Wingdings 2">&#161;</font></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">
      increased electric revenues of $75 million primarily due to $97 million in higher BGS and Non-Utility Generation (NGC) revenues (higher prices of $129 million offset by decreased sales of $32 million), offset by $22 million in lower non-utility generation (NUG) revenues,
      primarily due to lower prices, and</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:5.6mm; "><font face="Wingdings 2">&#161;</font></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">decreased gas revenues of $10 million due to $48 million in decreased BGSS prices offset by $38 million in higher sales due to weather.</FONT></P>
    <P style="text-indent:12.7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>



<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">

  <TR valign="top">

      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>
      Delivery </I></B>revenues increased $52 million due to</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>



<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:3.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:5.6mm; ">
      <font face="Wingdings 2">&#161;</font></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">
      increased gas revenues of $30 million due to $15 million of higher sales due to favorable weather and $15 million due to higher SBC revenues, and</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:5.6mm; "><font face="Wingdings 2">&#161;</font></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">increased electric revenues of $22 million due to $14 million for SBC revenues, $7 million for net transmission rate increases, $4 million for a securitization transition charge rate increase, offset by $3 million in decreased distribution sales and demands due to economic conditions.
      PSE&amp;G retains no margins from SBC or STC collections as the revenues are offset in operating expenses below.</FONT></P>
    <P style="text-indent:12.7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">54</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Operating Expenses</B></FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-size:4.2mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>
      Energy Costs </I></B>increased $66 million due to</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>



<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:3.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:5.6mm; ">
      <font face="Wingdings 2">&#161;</font></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">
      increased electric costs of $75 million due to $120 million or 16% in higher prices for BGS and NUG purchases offset by $45 million or 6% in lower BGS and NUG volumes due to economic conditions, offset by</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:sans-serif; font-size:5.6mm; "><font face="Wingdings 2">&#161;</font></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">decreased gas costs of $10 million due to $48 million or 5% lower prices offset by $38 million or 4% in higher sales volumes due to favorable weather.</FONT></P>
    <P style="text-indent:12.7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">For the quarter ended March 31, 2009, the primary reasons for the $22 million decrease in Income from Continuing Operations were:</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right"><P><FONT style="font-size:4.2mm; ">
      &#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><P><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></td>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">
      lower tax benefits as a result of the absence of benefits recorded in 2008 related to an IRS refund claim,</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:4.2mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">lower generation revenues, and</FONT></P>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">55</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">


  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:8pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:4.2mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">lower leveraged lease revenues primarily due to the tax reserve taken in mid-2008 and the sale of leveraged lease assets,</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:4.2mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">partially offset by gains on sales and terminations of leveraged lease assets, and</FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:4pt;"><p style="margin-top:0pt;">&nbsp;</p></td>

  </TR>
  <TR valign="top">
    <TD align="right">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-size:4.2mm; ">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17">
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">lower interest expense due to debt retirement.</FONT></P>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>

<P style="text-indent:7.7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">The quarter-over-quarter details for these variances are discussed below:</FONT></P>

<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">56</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Income from Discontinued Operations, net of tax </B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">During 2008, we sold our investments in SAESA Group and Bioenergie. Income from Discontinued Operations relating to these investments for the quarter ended March 31, 2008 totaled $13 million. See Note&nbsp;3. Discontinued Operations and Dispositions for additional information.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=liquidity1>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">The following discussion of our liquidity and capital resources is on a consolidated basis, noting the uses and contributions, where material, of our three direct operating subsidiaries.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Operating Cash Flows</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Our operating cash flows combined with cash on hand and financing activities are expected to be sufficient to fund capital expenditures and shareholder dividend payments.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">For the quarter ended March 31, 2009, our operating cash flow increased by $346 million as compared to the same quarter in 2008. The net change was due to net changes from our subsidiaries as discussed below.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0 12.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Power&#146;s operating cash flow increased $325 million from $938 million to $1,263 million for the quarter ended March 31, 2009, as compared to the same period in 2008, primarily resulting from an increase of $223 million in net cash collateral receipts and an increase of $211 million from net
  collections of counterparty receivables, partially offset by contributions of $78 million to the employee pension plan in 2009.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0 12.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">PSE&amp;G&#146;s operating cash flow decreased $45 million from $261 million to $216 million for the quarter ended March 31, 2009, as compared to the same period in 2008, primarily due to $153 million in increased pension fund contributions. This was offset by $111 million in higher recovery of
  regulatory assets.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:4.2mm 0 0 12.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Energy Holdings&#146; operating cash flow increased $96 million from $(138) million to $(42) million for the quarter ended March 31, 2009, as compared to the same period in 2008. The increase was mainly attributable to tax payments made in 2008 related to the sales of certain equity method
  investments.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Short-Term Liquidity</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">We have been managing our liquidity to assure that we continue to have sufficient access to cash to operate our businesses in the event the capital markets do not allow for near-term financing at reasonable terms. We are also closely monitoring the financial condition and concentration of lenders
  in our bank facilities. There is no provision in any of the credit facilities that would require other lenders in the facility to assume loan commitments of any financial institution that fails to meet its loan commitments. As of March 31, 2009, no single institution represents more than 11% of the
  commitments in our credit facilities.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">We continually monitor our liquidity and seek to add capacity as needed to meet our liquidity requirements. Each of our credit facilities is restricted as to availability and use to the specific companies as listed below; </FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">57</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">however, if necessary, the PSEG facilities can also be used to support our subsidiaries&#146; liquidity needs. Our total credit facilities and available liquidity as of March 31, 2009 were as follows:</FONT></P>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">On April 3, 2009, Power executed a $150 million bilateral credit agreement to replace a $150 million credit agreement that expired during March 2009. The new credit agreement is available for funding and the issuance of letters of credit and expires on September 30, 2009.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">In the second and third quarters of 2009, $250 million of bilateral credit facilities at PSEG and Power are scheduled to expire. While we expect to request renewal of each of these facilities, no assurances can be given that such facilities will be renewed or renewed on comparable terms.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Long-Term Debt Financing</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">In February 2009, Energy Holdings redeemed the remaining $280 million outstanding non-recourse project debt associated with the assets of PSEG Texas. The debt was scheduled to mature on December 31, 2009. PSEG and PSE&amp;G have $249 million and $60 million, respectively, of debt
  maturities upcoming in 2009, excluding securitized and nonrecourse debt. These maturities will occur in late May 2009 for PSE&amp;G and during the third and fourth quarters for PSEG. We believe that we will be able to refinance or retire these obligations assuming continued access to the capital
  markets. For a discussion of our long-term debt transactions during 2009, see Note 6. Changes in Capitalization.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">58</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Common Stock Dividends and Repurchases</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Dividend payments on common stock for the quarter ended March 31, 2009 were $0.3325 per share and totaled $168 million. Dividend payments on common stock for the quarter ended March 31, 2008 were $0.3225 per share and totaled $164 million.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">In July 2008, our Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to $750 million of our common stock to be executed over 18 months beginning August 1, 2008. We are not obligated to acquire any specific number of shares and may suspend or terminate share repurchases at any time. We
  repurchased 2,382,200 shares of our common stock for $92 million under this authorization through September 30, 2008. No repurchases have been made since that date.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">On April 21, 2009, our Board of Directors approved a common stock dividend of $0.3325 per share for the second quarter of 2009. This reflects an indicated annual dividend rate of $1.33 per share. We expect to continue to pay cash dividends on our common stock; however, the declaration and
  payment of future dividends to holders of our common stock will be at the discretion of the Board of Directors and will depend upon many factors, including our financial condition, earnings, capital requirements of our business, alternate investment opportunities, legal requirements, regulatory
  constraints, industry practice and other factors that the Board of Directors deems relevant.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Credit Ratings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">If the rating agencies lower or withdraw our credit ratings, such revisions may adversely affect the market price of our securities and serve to materially increase our cost of capital and limit access to capital. Outlooks assigned to ratings are as follows: stable, negative (Neg) or positive (Pos).
  There is no assurance that the ratings will continue for any given period of time or that they will not be revised by the rating agencies, if, in their respective judgments, circumstances warrant. Each rating given by an agency should be evaluated independently of the other agencies&#146; ratings. The
  ratings should not be construed as an indication to buy, hold or sell any security. In March 2009, S&amp;P affirmed the ratings and outlooks of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings.</FONT></P>

<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">59</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=capital1>CAPITAL REQUIREMENTS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">We expect that the majority of funding for our capital requirements over the next three years will come from internally generated funds. The balance will be provided by the issuance of debt at the respective subsidiary or project level and by equity contributions from us to our subsidiaries.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">PSE&amp;G&#146;s projected construction and investment expenditures through 2011 are expected to increase by $778 million as compared to amounts previously reported, primarily due to $694 million of spending accelerated from later years under the Capital Economic Stimulus Program approved by the
  BPU in April 2009. These expenditures will be financed by a combination of external capital and internally generated funds.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Other than this increase at PSE&amp;G, our projected construction and investment expenditures through 2011 are consistent with the amounts disclosed in our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2008.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">During the quarter ended March 31, 2009, Power made $162 million of capital expenditures (excluding $45 million for nuclear fuel), primarily related to various projects at Fossil and Nuclear. For additional information regarding current projects, see Note 5. Commitments and Contingent
  Liabilities.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">During the quarter ended March 31, 2009, PSE&amp;G made $194 million of capital expenditures, primarily for reliability of transmission and distribution systems. The $194 million does not include expenditures for cost of removal, net of salvage, of $9 million, which are included in operating cash
  flows.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=accounting1>ACCOUNTING MATTERS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">For information related to recent accounting matters, see Note 2. Recent Accounting Standards.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:-20.7mm; margin:6.3mm 0 0 20.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:5.2mm; "><B><a name=item3>ITEM 3. QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">The market risk inherent in our market-risk sensitive instruments and positions is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in commodity prices, equity security prices and interest rates as discussed in the notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements. It is our policy to use
  derivatives to manage risk consistent with business plans and prudent practices. We have a Risk Management Committee comprised of executive officers who utilize a risk oversight function to ensure compliance with our corporate policies and risk management practices.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Additionally, we are exposed to counterparty credit losses in the event of non-performance or non-payment. We have a credit management process, which is used to assess, monitor and mitigate counterparty exposure. In the event of non-performance or non-payment by a major counterparty, there
  may be a material adverse impact on our financial condition, results of operations or net cash flows.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Commodity Contracts</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">The availability and price of energy-related commodities are subject to fluctuations from factors such as weather, environmental policies, changes in supply and demand, state and federal regulatory policies, market rules and other events. To reduce price risk caused by market fluctuations, we enter
  into supply contracts and derivative contracts, including forwards, futures, swaps and options with approved counterparties. These contracts, in conjunction with demand obligations, help reduce risk and optimize the value of owned electric generation capacity.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0 12.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Value-at-Risk (VaR) Models</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">We use VaR models to assess the market risk of our commodity businesses. The portfolio VaR model includes our owned generation and physical contracts, as well as fixed price sales requirements, load requirements and financial derivative instruments. VaR represents the potential gains or
  losses, under normal </FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">60</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">market conditions, for instruments or portfolios due to changes in market factors, for a specified time period and confidence level. We estimate VaR across our commodity businesses.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">We manage our exposure at the portfolio level, which consists of owned generation, load-serving contracts (both gas and electric), fuel supply contracts and energy derivatives designed to manage the risk around generation and load. While we manage our risk at the portfolio level, we also
  monitor separately the risk of our trading activities and hedges. Non-trading mark-to-market (MTM) VaR consists of MTM derivatives that are economic hedges, some of which qualify for hedge accounting. The MTM derivatives that are not hedges are included in the trading VaR.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">The VaR models used are variance/covariance models adjusted for the change of positions with a 95% confidence level and a one-day holding period for the MTM trading and non-trading activities and a 95% confidence level with a one-week holding period for the portfolio VaR. The models
  assume no new positions throughout the holding periods; however, we actively manage our portfolio.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Increased trading activities during 2009 have led to a higher VaR as compared to December 31, 2008. As of March 31, 2009, trading VaR was $2 million. As of December 31, 2008, trading VaR was $1 million.</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%; border:solid .5pt black; margin-top:6pt;" >
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD style="width:67.60%;"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>

    <TD style="width:11.12%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="bottom">
    <TD style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>
      For the Quarter Ended March 31, 2009</B></FONT></P></TD>

    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>

    <TD colspan="2" style="background:#e6e6e6; ">&nbsp;</TD>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Credit Risk</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Credit risk relates to the risk of loss that we would incur as a result of non-performance by counterparties pursuant to the terms of their contractual obligations. We have established credit policies that we believe significantly minimize credit risk. These policies include an evaluation of potential
  counterparties&#146; financial condition (including credit rating), collateral requirements under certain circumstances and the use of standardized agreements, which allow for the netting of positive and negative exposures associated with a single counterparty.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">In the event of non-performance or non-payment by a major counterparty, there may be a material adverse impact on Power&#146;s financial condition, results of operations or net cash flows. As of March 31, 2009, 98% of the credit exposure (MTM plus net receivables and payables, less cash
  collateral) for Power&#146;s operations was with investment grade counterparties.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">The following table provides information on Power&#146;s credit exposure, net of collateral, as of March 31, 2009. Credit exposure is defined as any positive results of netting accounts receivable/accounts payable and the forward value on open positions. It further delineates that exposure by the credit
  rating of the </FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">61</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">counterparties and provides guidance on the concentration of credit risk to individual counterparties and an indication of the maturity of a company&#146;s credit risk by credit rating of the counterparties.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Schedule of Credit Risk Exposure on Energy Contracts Net<br>Assets as of March 31, 2009</B></FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%; border:solid .5pt black; margin-top:6pt;" >

    <TD align="right" style="background:#e6e6e6; "><P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">
      PSE&amp;G is a counterparty with net exposure of $769 million. The remaining net exposure of $166 million is with a nonaffiliated power purchaser which is a regulated investment grade counterparty.</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>


<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">The net exposure listed above, in some cases, will not be the difference between the current exposure and the collateral held. A counterparty may have posted more cash collateral than the outstanding exposure, in which case there would not be exposure. When letters of credit have been posted as
  collateral, the exposure amount is not reduced, but the exposure amount is transferred to the rating of the issuing bank. As of March 31, 2009, Power had 148 active counterparties.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:-20.7mm; margin:4.2mm 0 0 20.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:5.2mm; "><B><a name=item4>ITEM 4. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Disclosure Controls and Procedures</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">We have established and maintain disclosure controls and procedures as defined under Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the &#147;Exchange Act&#148;) that are designed to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be
  disclosed in the reports that are filed or submitted under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported and is accumulated and communicated to the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of each respective company, as appropriate, by others within the entities to
  allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure. We have established a disclosure committee which includes several key management employees and which reports directly to the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each respective company. The committee monitors and
  evaluates the effectiveness of these disclosure controls and procedures. The Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each company have evaluated the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures and, based on this evaluation, have concluded that disclosure controls and
  procedures at each respective company were effective at a reasonable assurance level as of the end of the period covered by the report.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Internal Controls</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:0mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">We continually review our disclosure controls and procedures
and make changes, as necessary, to ensure the quality of our financial reporting. There have been no changes in internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the first quarter of 2009 that have materially affected,
  or are reasonably likely to materially affect, each registrant&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">62</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>

<P align="center" style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:5.2mm; "><B><a name=partii>PART II. OTHER INFORMATION</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=p2item1>ITEM 1. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">We are party to various lawsuits and regulatory matters in the ordinary course of business. For information regarding material legal proceedings, including updates to information reported under Item 3 of Part I of the respective 2008 Annual Reports on Form 10-K of PSEG, Power and PSE&amp;G, see
  Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities and Item 5. Other Information, Regulatory Issues.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>RPM Model</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>PJM FERC Filing to Prospectively Change Elements of RPM and FERC Order on PJM Filing</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>2008 Form 10-K, Page 43. </I></B>PJM submitted a filing at FERC seeking to implement certain prospective changes to the RPM model. Issues in this proceeding included:</FONT></P>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">On March 26, 2009, the FERC issued an order accepting various parts and rejecting others, including retaining CONE values and reducing RPM auction requirements to encourage participation. While we believe that the order is generally positive, we sought rehearing of this order for further
  adjustments to PJM&#146;s filing.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=p2item1a>ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">There are no additional Risk Factors to be added to those disclosed in Part I Item 1A of our 2008 Annual Reports on Form 10-K.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=p2item2>ITEM 2. UNREGISTERED SALES OF EQUITY SECURITIES AND USE OF PROCEEDS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">In July 2008, our Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to $750 million of our Common Stock to be executed over 18 months beginning August 1, 2008. We are not obligated to acquire any specific number of shares and may suspend or terminate the share repurchases at any time.
  As of March 31, 2009, 2,382,200 shares were repurchased at a total price of $92 million.</FONT></P>

<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=p2item4>ITEM 4. SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Our Annual Meeting of Stockholders was held on April 21, 2009. Proxies for the meeting were solicited pursuant to Regulation 14A under the Securities Act of 1934. There was no solicitation of proxies in opposition to management&#146;s nominees as listed in the proxy statement and all of
  management&#146;s nominees were elected to the Board of Directors. Details of the voting are provided below:</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%; border:solid .5pt black; margin-top:6pt;" >
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD style="width:56.64%;"><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:10.91%;" colspan="6"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>

<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=p2item5>ITEM 5. OTHER INFORMATION</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Certain information reported under the 2008 Annual Report on Form 10-K is updated below. Additionally, certain information is provided for new matters that have arisen subsequent to the filing of the 2008 Annual Report on Form 10-K. References are to the related pages on the Form 10-K as
  printed and distributed.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.9mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>FEDERAL REGULATION</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Transmission Expansion</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>2008 Form 10-K, Page 19. </I></B>PJM has approved the construction of a 500 kV transmission line running from Virginia through Maryland and Delaware and is still considering approval of the portion terminating in Lower Alloways Creek Township, New Jersey. We will be responsible for
  constructing and operating a portion of this line, known as the Mid-Atlantic Pathway Project (MAPP), if its portion of the line is approved. In March 2009, we obtained from FERC approval of a 150 basis point ROE adder for this project (yielding a ROE of 13.18%), 100% recovery of
  abandonment costs and the ability to transfer the project to an affiliate. Receipt of incentive rates is contingent upon our portion of the MAPP project being approved by PJM as a RTEP project.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">In December 2008, PJM approved another transmission project, including two additional 500 kV transmission lines, and has assigned construction responsibility to PSE&amp;G. The first line would run from Branchburg to Roseland, and the second from Roseland to Hudson. These lines are still in the
  design phase.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Congestion Study&#151;National Interest Electric Transmission Corridors and FERC Back-Stop Siting Authority</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>2008 Form 10-K, Page 20. </I></B>In October 2007, the DOE acted to designate transmission corridors within these critical congestion areas. One of the designated corridors is the Mid-Atlantic Area National Corridor. Thus, entities seeking to build transmission within the Mid-Atlantic Area Corridor,
  which includes New Jersey, most of Pennsylvania and New York, may be able to use the FERC&#146;s back-stop siting authority in the future under certain circumstances, if necessary, to site transmission, including with respect to the Susquehanna-Roseland line. On February 18, 2009, the United
  States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit narrowed the scope of the FERC&#146;s back-stop siting authority. FERC has sought reconsideration of this Court of Appeals decision.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">64</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>STATE REGULATION</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.8mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Energy Supply</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.8mm 0 0 12.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>BGSS</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>2008 Form 10-K, Page 23. </I></B>In May 2008, PSE&amp;G requested an increase in annual BGSS revenue of $376 million, excluding Sales and Use Tax, to be effective October 1, 2008. Since that time, due to the significant downward trend in wholesale natural gas prices, we filed three revisions to the
  BGSS increase, a revised Stipulation (increase of 14% or $267 million), a BGSS self-implementing decrease (5% or approximately $108 million) and a second BGSS self-implementing decrease (7% or approximately $145 million). The increase in the BGSS-Residential Service Gas (RSG) rate
  became effective on October 3, 2008 and the decreases became effective on January 1, 2009 and March 1, 2009, respectively.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Energy Policy</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.8mm 0 0 12.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Solar Initiatives</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>2008 Form 10-K, Page 23. </I></B>We are investing approximately $105 million over two years in a pilot program to help finance the installation of 30 MW of solar systems throughout our utility&#146;s electric service area by providing loans to customers for the installation of solar photovoltaic (PV)
  systems on their premises. As of April 24, 2009, we have provided approximately $9 million in loans for approximately 2 MW of solar systems.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">In February 2009, we filed a new solar initiative with the BPU called the Solar 4 All Program. Through this program, we would invest approximately $773 million to develop 120 MW of solar PV systems over a five-year horizon. The program consists of a centralized PV system (35MW), solar
  systems installed on distribution system poles (40MW), roof-mounted systems installed on local government buildings in our electric service territory (43MW) and roof-mounted solar systems installed in New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency affordable housing communities (2MW).
  This program remains under review by the BPU.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">On March 31, 2009, we also filed a new solar loan program, called &#147;Solar Loan II&#148;, with the BPU. This program is modeled on the original solar loan pilot program discussed above. Under Solar Loan II, we would help finance the installation of an additional 40 MW of solar systems in our
  electric service territory. Any remaining financing and capacity from the original solar loan program would be rolled into the new program.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.8mm 0 0 12.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Capital Economic Stimulus Infrastructure Program</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>2008 Form 10-K, Page 25. </I></B>On January 21, 2009, we filed for approval of a capital economic stimulus infrastructure investment program. Under this initiative, we proposed to undertake $698 million of capital infrastructure investments for electric and gas programs over a 24 month period. The
  goal of these accelerated capital investments is to help improve the State&#146;s economy through the creation of new jobs. This filing was made in response to the Governor of New Jersey&#146;s proposal to help revive the economy through job growth and capital spending.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">The BPU approved a settlement agreement on April 16, 2009 which identified 38 qualifying projects totaling $694 million. These projects are expected to create more than 900 new jobs. On April 28, 2009, we received the BPU&#146;s written order which was effective May 1, 2009.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">Under the program new Capital Adjustment Charges (CAC) will provide for immediate recovery of a return on program expenditures plus depreciation of the assets. The CAC&#146;s will be adjusted each January based on forecasted program expenditures and will be subject to deferred accounting. The
  rates are subject to annual adjustments based on actual expenditures and actual general and economic market conditions.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0 12.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Susquehanna-Roseland BPU Petition</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><I>2008 Form 10-K, Page 25. </I></B>In January 2009, we filed a Petition with the BPU seeking authorization from the BPU to construct the New Jersey portion of the Susquehanna-Roseland line. The New Jersey portion of the line spans approximately 45 miles and crosses through 16 municipalities. The
  Petition seeks a finding from the BPU that municipal land use and zoning ordinances of these municipalities do not apply to this line. A procedural schedule has been established, under which the BPU expects to issue a decision in December 2009. We are also in the process of seeking to obtain
  all necessary environmental permits for the project.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">65</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>

<P><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=p2item6>ITEM 6. EXHIBITS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:serif; font-size:4.2mm; ">A listing of exhibits being filed with this document is as follows:</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:4.39%;margin-right:4.39%;width:91.22%;" >
<TR valign="top">
    <TD style="width:3.39%;"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:14.29%;"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><P><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>

  </TR>
